entry.title: A tour of IHaskell extensions and integrations
entry.summary: In my previous post, I tried to provide a step-by-step explanation of how to install IHaskell on Ubuntu 14.04 (Should also work on other versions). Now is time to start using it! This post is an overview of various extensions you can use within IHaskell.

entry.title: Install IHaskell on Ubuntu 14.04 with Stack
entry.summary: In this post, we're going through the installation of IHaskell on GNU/Linux (Ubuntu 14.04 in my case, though it should be pretty similar on other ditributions) step-by-step. We'll see how the use of Stack will simplify the whole process, and how to get all the dependencies right!

entry.title: [py.test] Paramaterize tests with external data
entry.summary: I recently began to make heavy use of py.test in my day-to-day Python development. It's a wonderful tool, but I won't explain to you every features it provides and why it's awesome. Instead, I'll explain how I managed to cleanly externalize the data used for my tests in external files (that can be of any format: yaml, json, python files). The idea here is to separate the code that performs the test, from the input data used to perform the test.

entry.title: Decompressing BZipped files with Julia
entry.summary: I'm currently working with Wikipedia dumps, and to save space, it's a good thing to make scripts that read directly content from (and write results to) BZipped files.
